newsitem.title: USA: Dlr finishes lower in U.S., back below 1.48 marks.
newsitem.headline: Dlr finishes lower in U.S., back below 1.48 marks.

text.p: The dollar finished weaker against most major currencies, pressured by growing dissatisfaction with its failure to sustain a rally even after a large cut in the German repo rate, experts said.

"The market is very disappointed with the reaction of the dollar yesterday after the Bundesbank move," said Chris Iggo, an international economist at Barclays Bank Plc. "Most people would have thought that the dollar should have gone higher after the larger-than-expected cut in the repo rate."
On Thursday, the Bundesbank had lowered its repo rate to 3.0 percent, a historic low.
Many traders had expected the Bundesbank to only lower the rate by 10 or 15 basis points, but instead, the central bank knocked off 30 basis points.
The dollar closed at 1.4775/85 marks, down from 1.4876/79 at the open.
The dollar fell to 108.10/20 yen from 108.40/50 and to 1.1925/35 Swiss francs from 1.2044/51 at the open.
Losses accelerated after stop loss sell orders were triggered when the dollar fell below 1.20 francs first and then below 1.48 marks, experts said.

"People are basically selling their long dollar positions against the mark, and against the Swiss, they're initiating short dollar positions," said David Durrant, a senior currency strategist at I.D.E.A. Inc, a consulting firm. "So, you're getting a double-barreled effect here."
The dollar declines occurred in typically slow summer volume, experts said. Therefore, currency traders were careful not to read too much into the trend.
"It's a very thin Friday afternoon market, and it's very vulnerable to exaggerated moves," said Adam Adelman, a trader at Banque Paribas.

With the Buba repo rate cut behind it, the foreign exchange market faces the release of Japan's quarterly "Tankan" survey sometime next week along with the revision to second-quarter real U.S. gross domestic product (GDP) on Thursday at 0830 EDT/1230 GMT.
U.S. economists polled by Reuters, on average, expect the GDP revision to come in at 4.2 percent, unchanged from the first estimate.
In other trade, the dollar closed at Canadian $1.3705/10, slightly above C$1.3700/05 at the open. Sterling rose to US$1.5562/69 from US$1.5535/45.
